studies.title: Bioaccumulation of therapeutic drugs by human gut bacteria (B.animalis assays)
studies.description:
Bacteria in the gut can modulate the availability and efficacy of therapeutic drugs. Interactions at this level have only recently started to being systematically mapped and the main underlying mechanism proposed is chemical transformation of drugs by microbes (biotransformation). Here, we investigated the depletion of structurally diverse drugs by 25 representative gut bacterial strains. This revealed 70 bacteria-drug interactions, 29 of which had not been reported before. Over half of the new interactions can be ascribed to bioaccumulation, that is bacteria storing the drug intracellularly without chemically modifying it, and in most cases without their growth being affected. As a case in point, we studied the molecular basis of bioaccumulation of the widely used antidepressant duloxetine by using click-chemistry, thermal proteome profiling and metabolomics. We find that duloxetine binds to several metabolic enzymes and changes metabolite secretion of the respective bacteria. When tested in a defined microbial community of accumulators and non-accumulators, duloxetine markedly altered the community composition through metabolic cross-feeding. We further validated our findings in an animal model, showing that bioaccumulating bacteria attenuate the behavioral response of Caenorhabditis elegans to duloxetine. Taken together, bioaccumulation by gut bacteria may be a common mechanism that alters drug availability and bacterial metabolism, with implications for microbiota composition, pharmacokinetics, side effects and drug responses, likely in an individual manner.


Linked studies;

UPLC-MS/MS assay of Lacrimispora saccharolytica and Escherichia coli IAI1 is reported in MTBLS1319.

UPLC-MS/MS assays of Escherichia coli ED1a, Clostridium saccharolyticum, Escherichia coli IAI1, Streptococcus salivarius, Eubacterium rectale, Lactobacillus plantarum WCFS1 and Lactococcus lactis subsp. lactis Il1403 are reported in MTBLS1627.

UPLC-MS/MS assay of Bacteroides uniformis and Clostridium saccharolyticum is reported in MTBLS1757.

UPLC-MS/MS assay of Clostridium saccharolyticum, Escherichia coli ED1a, Escherichia coli IAI1, Lactobacillus plantarum WCFS1, Lactococcus lactis subsp. lactis Il1403 and Streptococcus salivarius is reported in MTBLS1791.

UPLC-MS/MS assay of Eubacterium rectale and Streptococcus salivarius is reported in MTBLS1792.

UPLC-MS/MS assay of Lacrimispora saccharolytica and standards is reported in MTBLS2885.

publications.title: Bioaccumulation of therapeutic drugs by human gut bacteria.
publications.authorList: Klünemann M, Andrejev S, Blasche S, Mateus A, Phapale P, Devendran S, Vappiani J, Simon B, Scott TA, Kafkia E, Konstantinidis D, Zirngibl K, Mastrorilli E, Banzhaf M, Mackmull MT, Hövelmann F, Nesme L, Brochado AR, Maier L, Bock T, Periwal V, Kumar M, Kim Y, Tramontano M, Schultz C, Beck M, Hennig J, Zimmermann M, Sévin DC, Cabreiro F, Savitski MM, Bork P, Typas A, Patil KR.

protocols.name: Sample collection
protocols.description:
Unless otherwise indicated, all bacteria were grown as liquid cultures in Gut Microbiota Medium (GMM) [1]. Cultivations were carried out in a Vinyl Anaerobic Chamber (COY, USA) at 37 °C with oxygen below 20 ppm, 15% carbon dioxide and 1.8-2% hydrogen. Main gas in the anaerobic chamber was nitrogen. All experimental cultures were started from the second passage culture after inoculation from a glycerol or DMSO stock. All media, buffer, glass and plasticware used in the study were exposed to the anaerobic conditions at least 12 h prior to their usage.


Depletion Screen

For all drugs, a fixed concentration of 50 μM was used, which is within the colon concentration range estimated for many drugs. Triplicates for each bacterium-drug interaction and a single bacteria-free control were screened per plate and drug. The screen was carried out under anaerobic conditions in 96-well plates (Nunclon Delta Surface 163320, NUNC) with 150 μl GMM as the growth medium sealed with a Breathe-Easy® sealing membrane (Z380059, Sigma- Aldrich). Plates containing 100 μl of the medium and 75 μM of the drug (named ctrl or sample) or solvent (named GMM) were prepared beforehand, stored at -20 °C and used as needed. Frozen plates were introduced into the anaerobic chamber the evening before inoculation. Wells were inoculated with 50 μl of a second passage culture to reach starting OD578 of 0.01 (sample, GMM) or 50µl fresh media (ctrl). Growth was monitored by measuring optical densities at 578 nm using an Eon Microplate Spectrophotometer (BioTek) approximately every 2 h for the first 10 h, and then approximately every 6 h. After 48 h, plates were removed from the anaerobic chamber.


Activity Assay

Bacteria from second passage culture were inoculated at starting OD578 of 0.01 in 1 mL GMM containing 50 μM drug of interest (named sample) or the drug solvent alone (named GMM) in 2 mL eppendorf tubes and incubated for 48 h while shaking. Bacteria-free control samples containing 50 µM drug of interest (named ctrl) were treated the same. After 48h the cultures were removed from the anaerobic chamber. All interactions and controls were tested in triplicates.


Additional controls for drug auto-degradation

‘Cold’ samples are control samples where the drug containing media samples were directly extracted after defreezing and without exposing the plate to bacteria or to the culture conditions. ‘Warm’ samples are control samples where all samples (the drug conataining media samples) were exposed to bacteria culture conditions without any bacteria added and then extracted. StandardA and StandardB are 'warm' samples. Concentration before extraction was 50µM of the respective drug.



[1] Goodman, A. L. et al. Extensive personal human gut microbiota culture collections characterized and manipulated in gnotobiotic mice. P Natl Acad Sci USA 108, 6252--6257, doi:10.1073/pnas.1102938108 (2011).

protocols.name: Extraction
protocols.description:
Depletion Screen

Bacteria were spun down (4000 rpm, 10 min) to harvest the supernatant. 100 μl of it was extracted in 300 μl ice cold acetonitrile:methanol (Biosolve, ULC grade) in 500 μl polypropylene plates (Corning Costar 3957) to remove compounds interfering with liquid chromatography. Plates were closed with a lid (Corning, storage mat 3080) and after shaking and 15 minutes incubation at 4 °C, samples were centrifuged at 4000 rpm for 10 min at 4 °C and 300 μl of the supernatant were transferred to a new plate (Corning Costar 3362). All liquid handling outside of the anaerobic chamber was done using a ducted liquid handling robot (FXp, Biomek). Sample plates were then left overnight in a chemical hood to evaporate the organic phase, before being stored at -20 °C. For estimating the drug concentration in the samples with the UPLC, samples were reconstituted in 50 μl 20% acetonitrile solution containing 250 μM caffeine (Sigma) as an internal standard.


Activity Assay

800 μl of each sample was transferred to a new eppendorf tube, while the remaining 200 μl were directly extracted by adding 600 μl ice-cold acetonitrile:methanol solution and incubated for 15 min at 4 °C. For supernatant extraction, the transferred culture was centrifuged for 5 min at 14000 rpm to pellet the bacteria, and 200 μl of the bacteria-free supernatant was extracted in a new eppendorf tube, respectively. After the 15 min 4 °C incubation period, all samples were centrifuged for 10 min, 14.000 rpm at 4 °C and 700 μl of the supernatant was transferred to a new eppendorf tube. Samples were dried for 5-7 h at 30 °C in a speedvac (Eppendorf Vacuum Concentrator Plus, V-AL mode) and stored at -20 °C until used for UPLC measurement. Samples were reconstituted in 116 μl 20% acetonitrile containing 250 μM caffeine Sigma) as an internal standard.

protocols.name: Chromatography
protocols.description:
Targeted liquid chromatography analyses were run on a Waters Acquity UPLC H-Class instrument with a PDA detector and a quaternary solvent system. Each run was circa 5 minutes long, with a flow rate of 0.5 ml/min and run on a CSH C18 column (Waters, Part number 186005297) in reverse mode. The column was heated to 40°C and samples kept at 6 °C. All methods used 50% acetonitrile (Biosolve, ULC grade) for washing buffer, and 50% methanol (Biosolve, ULC grade) for purging buffer. As organic mobile phase, acetonitrile was used. The assay used two additional buffers besides water as hydrophilic mobile phase: 5 mM formic acid (Biosolve, ULC grade) of pH 3.2 and 5 mM ammonium formate (Ammonium hydroxide, ACS grade, Sigma) with pH adjusted to 8.3 using formic acid. Analysis of authentic standards was used to determine the optimal chromatographic method for each drug. Table 1 lists the five different chromatographic methods established for the different drugs. During the method development, we checked for the absence of interference from bacterial or growth medium metabolites by running bacteria-only and media samples. Carrier treated bacterial cultures were also included in the screen and the corresponding UPLC results were inspected for the absence of any peaks that could overlap with the drug peak. Samples containing Acetaminophen, Metronidazole, Levamisole, and Ranitidine were eluted with Method A. Samples containing Aripiprazole, Donepezil, Duloxetine, Digoxin, Loperamide, Rosiglitazone and Tenofovir were eluted with Method B. Samples containing Ezetimibe, Roflumilast, Rosuvastatin, Sulfasalazine and Tolmetin were eluted with Method C. Samples containing Metformin were eluted with Method D. Samples containing Montelukast or Simvastatin were eluted with Method E.


Table 1: Targeted Chromatography Methods

Method A

0 - 1.5 min 5% ACN, 0% Formic Acid buffer, 65% Ammonium Formate buffer, 30% Water

2.5 - 3 min 60% ACN, 0% Formic Acid buffer, 40% Ammonium Formate buffer, 0% Water

3.5 - 5 min 5% ACN, 0% Formic Acid buffer, 65% Ammonium Formate buffer, 30% Water

Method B

0 - 1.5 min 5% ACN, 65% Formic Acid buffer, 0% Ammonium Formate buffer, 30% Water

2.5 - 3 min 60% ACN, 40% Formic Acid buffer, 0% Ammonium Formate buffer, 0% Water

3.5 - 5 min 5% ACN, 65% Formic Acid buffer, 0% Ammonium Formate buffer, 30% Water

Method C

0 - 1.5 min 20% ACN, 60% Formic Acid buffer, 0% Ammonium Formate buffer, 20% Water

2.5 - 3 min 80% ACN, 20% Formic Acid buffer, 0% Ammonium Formate buffer, 0% Water

3.5 - 5 min 20% ACN, 60% Formic Acid buffer, 0% Ammonium Formate buffer, 20% Water

Method D

0 - 1.5 min 5% ACN, 0% Formic Acid buffer, 95% Ammonium Formate buffer, 0% Water

2.5 - 3 min 50% ACN, 0% Formic Acid buffer, 50% Ammonium Formate buffer, 0% Water

3.5 - 5 min 5% ACN, 0% Formic Acid buffer, 95% Ammonium Formate buffer, 0% Water

Method E

0 - 1.5 min 40% ACN, 60% Formic Acid buffer, 0% Ammonium Formate buffer, 0% Water

2.5 - 3 min 95% ACN, 5% Formic Acid buffer, 0% Ammonium Formate buffer, 0% Water

3.5 - 5 min 40% ACN, 60% Formic Acid buffer, 0% Ammonium Formate buffer, 0% Water


UV detection

Metabolites were detected using a Waters Acquity PDA detector. Every 0.5 seconds a full spectral scan ranging from 190 nm to 500 nm was performed for each chromatographic run. In some cases only a TUV detector was available. In these cases only the specific drug wavelength as listed in Metabolite identification protocol was measured.

protocols.name: Mass spectrometry
protocols.description: No mass spectrometry was performed for this assay.

protocols.name: Data transformation
protocols.description: Waters Acquity proprietary software Empower 2 was used to report and export the area under the curve, which was used as an approximate for drug concentration.

protocols.name: Metabolite identification
protocols.description:
The targeted liquid chromatography compound identifications were based on measurements of authentic standards on the same UPLC. All identifications were based on the following criteria: UV absorption wavelength and retention time in minutes within the previously established drug specific UPLC method. Waters Acquity proprietary software Empower 2 was used to report and export the area under the curve, which was used as an approximate for drug concentration. Details for the specific drug identifications are listed in Table 2. Typically, caffeine was identified with the same wavelength as the targeted drug. In cases where caffeine was not absorbing at that wavelength a second wavelength was used.


Table 2: Drug identification parameters

Drug; UV absorp-tion in nm; 2nd wave length?; UPLC Method; Peak elution time in min; Caffeine elution time

Acetaminophen; 244; -; A; 1.5; 3

Aripiprazole; 255; -; B; 3.3; 3

Donepezil; 268; -; B; 3.2; 3

Duloxetine; 230; -; B; 3.3; 3

Digoxin; 220; -; B; 3.5; 3

Ezetimibe; 234; -; C; 3.5; 0.7

Loperamide; 220; -; B; 3.5; 3

Metformin; 234; -; D; 0.7; 3.1

Montelukast; 344; 274; E; 3.8; -

Metronidazole; 330; 274; A; 1.9; 3

Levamisole; 225; -; A; 3.5; 3

Ranitidine; 313; 274; A; 3.3; 3

Roflumilast; 245; -; C; 3.6; 0.7

Rosiglitazone; 247; -; B; 3.1; 3

Rosuvastatin; 241; -; C; 3.3; 0.7

Simvastatin; 247; -; E; 3.7; 0.5

Sulfasalazine; 254; -; C; 3.7; 0.7

Tenofovir; 260; -; B; 3.4; 3

Tolmetin; 320; 274; C; 3.4; 0.7
